EDITORIAL.
HERE is great excitement among the students and this is due to the
approach of that momentous event which will take place next week,
the Hopkins—St. John's game. Everyone is discussing our prospects and all of the 'true sports" among the undergraduates are looking for bets. This year there will be no odds given by either side,
so far as we have been able to ascertain. Hopkins is doing every
,'11(
possible thing to back up the team, and we feel confident that the
ifsvvvvvvvv11
I
team will make every effort to win. We must win, and we will win.
The alumni are giving us as much support'as they can, in that
that they will turn out in large numbers to root for their Alma Mater,
and it is the duty of every undergraduate to be present at the game and to add his lusty
cheers to those of the alumni. We are sure that the undergraduates will make a good showing, but we want to be able to say that there was not one undergraduate who was not at the
game. A movement is on foot among the collegiate students to have a large band to play for
them at the game. This is an excellent idea, and should most certainly be encouraged and
carried out.
Our team will not be the only one which will have large crowds to back it, as the St.
John's alumni have been very busy organizing a reunion, and they will attend the game in a
large body accompanied by a band, which will try to drown the yells, songs and band of the
Hopkins men.

It must be great, it must bring a warm tickling to the heart, and a feeling like a tight
collar in the throat, to know that your whereabouts are known to your Alma Mater, and to
feel that your old classmates desire your presence at their first dinner together, since graduation, maybe twenty-five years ago, before even Walter Noir held forth in the basement. That
series of dinners arranged for Friday, makes us almost wish we were alumni ourselves.
The thanks of not only the graduates and alumni, but of the whole student body are
certainly due to the committee, which under the lead of Mr. Radcliffe has engineered a most
difficult undertaking. We are with it, body and soul, and this is our feeble way of voicing
our admiration of its object, and of the men who have made it possible.

HIS year we started out with the intention of having a new picture
on the cover of each issue of the NEWS-LETTER, but we have now
decided to offer a prize of two dollars for the best cover design submitted to the Board of Editors, before December first of this year.
The design may be either one of two kinds, namely—a conventional
design which will serve for all times; or a design such that a new
picture may be inserted in the center whenever desired. Each design
must contain the following wording: THE NEWS-LETTER, Published
.
by the Undergraduates and Johns Hopkins University. In case the
latter style of design is submitted there must accompany it a picture,
which will fit in the center of the design, and drawn on a separate sheet.
We reserve the right to use at our discretion, any drawing submitted, whether it is the
prize-winner or not.

Hopkins has suffered another great loss in the death of Prof. William K. Brooks, Professor of Zoology. The many students at the University who had a personal acquaintance with
Prof. Brooks, whether in class or otherwise were, greatly attached to him. He was also much
beloved by all the members of the faculty.
Suitable memorial exercises will be held at the University very shortly.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

4

A NEGLECTED CLASSIC.
HERBERT E. GREENE.

A recent correspondent of the Nation tells
of several amusing experiences that he has had
in teaching the Bible. On one occasion be
asked a class of forty, 'How many of you
college men think you could find the book of
Hezekiah in the Bible without using the index ?" Fifteen of the forty were certain that
they could accomplish this feat if they were
allowed five minutes for the search. A few
weeks later he put the same question to
another class of thirteen college men, every
one of whom was confident of success. Similar
experiences might be related by many who
have undertaken to teach college students.
Most teachers would agree that it is scarcely
possible to overstate the lack of familiarity
with the Bible that is shown to-day by young
men and women who are called educated.
Yet there can be no question as to the practical unanimity with which people affirm that
of all books the Bible is the most important.
It is a matter of common knowledge that
the Bible is more frequently quoted than any
other book,—often by those who would be
puzzled indeed if they were asked to trace
their quotations. English literature is saturated with Biblical allusion and Biblical quotation to such an extent that a reader who
has only a slight acquaintance with the Bible
cannot hope to read understandingly or appreciatively such poets as Chaucer, Spenser,
Shakspere, Milton, Dryden, Pope, Wordsworth, Byron, Tennyson, Browning, prose
writers such as Bacon, Burke, Carlyle, Ruskin,
Matthew Arnold. This means that practically
all of our great writers and most of our lesser
writers were Bible-reading men and women,
and that they assumed a familiarity with the
Bible on the part of those for whom they
wrote. A recent writer has not been guilty
of over-statement when he says, ``Certainly
an intimate acquaintance with the Bible is the
best possible preparation for a study of English literature." One may even venture to
assert that familiarity with the Bible is necessary to an understanding of the daily papers
and the current magazines.* Says another
recent writer, "The Biblical tradition impreg*The last number of Life assumes a knowledge of
the story of two of our Old Testament prophets.

nates all our fashions of thinking and speaking. A man totally unacquainted with the
sacred history would go through the world as
if deaf or blind. A people which loses familiarity with the Bible is exiled from its spiritual
and intellectual fatherland, and becomes a
tribe of outlaws." A prominent American
scholar has written of the Bible in the following words:—"These books contain a body of
history, poetry, and philosophy, the study of
which has done more than any other single
cause to modify the course and happiness of
thinking men on earth, and to color and direct
the whole course of modern civilization."
Those who read various statements regarding the ignorance of college students with a
smile of superiority,—a feeling that is not
always warranted,—are apt to reflect, sometimes to comment, upon how little the college
has done for the student. As a matter of fact,
the tests of college classes that we read of
from time to time are commonly made with
Freshmen.t These tests both indicate an interest on the part of the college, and show
that the responsibility for ignorance must be
placed farther back than the college. Most
classes contain a few students who show a
reasonable degree of familiarity with the Bible;
it usually appears that such familiarity has
been gained, not in the school, nor yet in the
church, but in the home. It is there, in
truth, that such an acquaintance is most
readily gained. Fathers and mothers who
really believe that an intimate knowledge of
the Bible is important will see to it that such
knowledge is gained in the home. No child
should be defrauded of an early acquaintance
with Jack and the Beanstalk and Little Red
Riding Hood; and among his early heroes,
endeared by long association, should be
Joseph and Moses, Gideon and David. Soon
after he knows by heart his nursery rhymes
he is ready to be taught the Ten Commandments and the Beatitudes.
The question may be raised, what is done
by the colleges for students who appear to be
so greatly in need of Bible instruction? Are
these students less ignorant when they
graduate than they are when they enter? The
I.Interesting accounts of tests of this kind may be
found in the Century for May, 1900, pages 123-128,
and for December, 1900, pages 273-276.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

colleges, it may be answered, do not undertake the kind of instruction that properly belongs to the church and the home; but many
colleges do provide systematic instruction in
the Bible, both in the original languages and
in English. In some colleges such courses
are prescribed; more frequently, however,
they are elective. Courses of the latter kind
are provided by the Johns Hopkins University.
The effect of an intimate acquaintance with
the Bible upon one's style is well known.
"Intense study of the Bible," says Coleridge,
"will keep any writer from being vulgar in
point of style." Other faults he may have,
but not the fault of common-placeness; his
diction is likely to be simple, choice, dignified. Acting upon this belief, we require of
every freshman the reading of a number of
English classics,—by Shakespere, Milton,
Thackeray, Hawthorne, for example,—and,
with these classics, of considerable portions of
the English Bible. We ask our students to
read the Bible as they read other literature,
several pages at a time; we do not ask them
to make a minute study of a few verses, tho
that method of study is sometimes necessary
and helpful to a better understanding both of
the Bible and of English literature. We have
received repeated testimony that never before
has the Bible been found so interesting as
when it has been studied as literature,—the
only phase of Bible study that our department can properly deal with.
One sometimes hears the question raised as
to whether a body of religious writings can
successfully be taught to students of various
religious faiths. The answer is, obviously,
that it can be taught, as has repeatedly been
done with success, if it is taught as literature.
Objections might, indeed, he made by narrowminded men; but I have never heard of such
objections at this university. Rather I have
found a keen and broad-minded interest in
whatever has been of interest to humanity.
All religious classics are deeply interesting,
most of all for us the great Hebrew and
Hellenistic classics that have had so profound
and far-reaching an influence upon all civilized nations. It would manifestly be improper to make use of university classes for
teaching one's own religious views; but if

5

some of our English poems, by Wordsworth
and Shelley for example, cannot be understood without reference to the teaching of
Plato, much less can English literature, in its
long history of twelve hundred years, be
understood by one who is unacquainted with
the Old and the New Testaments. One who
does not know the beautiful story of Ruth cannot fully enjoy Keats's Ode lo a Nightingale;
one who has not read the book of Judges cannot understand Tennyson's Dream of Fair
Women; one who is not acquainted with the
parables of Jesus misses something when he
tries to read Tennyson's Guinevere. It for this
reason that considerable portions of the Bible
are included in the freshman course of reading; that an historical sketch of the English
Bible is included in one of our elective courses;
and that in the study of any author a familiarity with Biblical quotations and allusions is
expected wherever such familiarity is needed
for an understanding of the thought and
meaning of that author.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—The inter-fraternity treaty proposed
by THE NEWS-LETTER is the right sort. Perhaps the plan is too complicated to work.
Maybe the proposed inter-fraternity secretary
would know too much about the affairs of
other fraternities than his own. Perhaps the
penalty is vague. Anybody can find some
fault with the scheme. But that's no reason
for not having any scheme at all. Unless a
man can deny the truth of your preamble (I
don't see how he can) he ought to favor your
plan or a better one. What we want now is
to see the active members of the Hopkins
fraternities get together and talk the matter
over sensibly. When they agree on a plan,
let them go ahead. If one or two fainthearted chapters won't come in, let them stay
out; and public opinion,particularly fraternityalumni opinion, will be squarely behind the
chapters that stands for dignity and public
spirit. In the end, those chapters will get all
the good men they want, for the good men
will wait to see what they are going to do.

ALUMNUS.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

6
_

To the Board of Editors
of THE NEWS- LETTER:

DEAR SIR—The fraternity treaty recently
proposed by THE NEWS-LETTER has left
many of us in a haze of doubt over the practibility of it. Here are several points that the
author, or authors, have evidently overlooked.
First, they say that the treaty is founded
upon the inter-club treaty at Princeton; evidently they are unaware that last year two of
the leading clubs at Princeton dropped out of
the treaty, saying, that while they considered
the idea of the treaty sound, that it was tinpracticable, because there was no way to
enforce it.
The same is true of the situation at Johns
Hopkins. While the idea of the treaty is
good, so far as all practicable purpose goes, it
is worthless. Such a treaty must have as its
foundation, either perfect confidence between
the fraternities, or some penalty so severe,
that the breaking of the treaty would be out
of the question. At a Pan-Hellenic Council,
last year, a treaty along these same general
lines was agitated, its purpose being to put a
stop to early pledging. This treaty failed to
be adopted for the reason that the several
fraternities at the University were unwilling
to enter into an agreement with each other
where the honor of the fraternities was the
only guarantee of the treaty being kept. This
situation is indeed lamentable, but is only the
direct result of inter-fraternity politics during
the last few years.
The penalty proposed in the NEws-LETTER
treaty is utterly inadequate. ''In case of a
charge being brought against a fraternity, the
delegates of that fraternity to the Pan-Hellenic
Council, shall investigate the charge and
report their findings in the same to the council
That is all very well, but if the accusation is
true, how much may you expect the members
of the fraternity to admit? From my experience with inter-fraternity policies at Hopkins,
I should scarcely expect to find a fraternity
sacrificing itself to the general good. And
again the secret nature of fraternities is such
that no one but a member of the fraternity
would be in a position to investigate the
charge against the said fraternity. Here, we
have all the Princeton troubles at their worst

with an added complication in the way of the
secret nature of a fraternity.
Again, can a fraternity situated in a city,
with a large number of alumni about it, be
responsible for the actions of those alumni?
The Princeton clubs had no such alumni in
daily contact with it. Article III, Section 6,
Clause 2, provides that if an incoming freshman is unable to sign the oath in Article III,
Section 5, through action on his part caused
by ignorance of the conditions that he be at
liberty to join any fraternity sending him an
invitation, no previous pledge being binding.
What is to prevent an alumnus of a chapter
pledging a man before entrance? The fraternity with all fairness, may disclaim all responsibility for the action of the alumnus, yet
reap the benefits of it.
The only clause in the treaty which would be
of practical use is that clause which prohibits
sub-freshman the privilege of entering a
fraternity house before March 1st, of the year
before they enter. But with Hopkins, the
men are not sure just what year they will
enter, so in many cases this rule may be
broken through no intention of the fraternity.
And this clause alone would be of little use in
breaking up the present abuses.
A house of cards balanced upon a toothpick is not a very edifying sight. The authors
of THE NEWS-LETTER treaty seem to count
it nothing that their treaty has already
failed under much more favorable conditions
than are offered at Hopkins, and that several
of the Hopkins fraternities have within the
last year signified their unwillingness to enter
into any treaty of this nature.
Very truly yours,
ALAN CHuRcHILL WOODS.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
At a meeting of the Trustees held November 2nd, President Remsen resigned the position of Director of the Chemical Laboratory,
which he has held from the beginning of the
University. Prof. Harmon N. Morse was
appointed Director of the Chemical Laboratory
and his title changed to that of Professor of
Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry. President Remsen will continue to lecture as in
past years and to take the same part in the
work of the advanced students.

The laying of a new ceiling over the rooms
of the Classical Department proves to be
quite a noisy affair. Someone has suggested
that we have here a revival of the "Lays of
Ancient Rome."

position as to compel Halswelle to run very

Mr. David Basan (Amateur Athletic Association and London Athletic Club), acting as

Dr. Badger, and corroborated his evidence in
every particular, further adding that, in his
opinion, Mr. Halswelle was wilfully obstructed.

Council, and honorary secretary of the Scottish
Amateur Athletic Association) stated .that he
acted as referee for this race, and took up his
position opposite the winning post, where he
watched the race very carefully in the last
straight. He stated that on swinging into
the straight Halswelle commenced to gain on
the man in front, whereupon Carpenter went
straight to the outside edge of the track, while
Robbins nipped through on the inside. The
boring by Carpenter continued, and the umpires held up their hands to signal the
foul.

Fisher, consulted with Mr. David ScottDuncan, and on the evidence of the umpires

ST. JOHN'S AND B. M. C.
When the 'Varsity team meets St. John's
in the annual big game next Saturday, one of
the toughest football battles ever fought in
this city will undoubtedly result. St. John's
has the greatest team in its history this year,
and the same may be said of Hopkins, for our
team has made a great record this year. Our
defeat at the hands of Delaware was one of
those things that will happen to the best of
teams when luck, weather conditions and
sickness are against them.
St. John's has played eight games this year
and has won six of them, losing to the University of Virginia and the Naval Academy.
Their record up-to-date stands, 147 points
won against 63 lost. This is certainly an
enviable record when one thinks of the caliber
of the teams that St. John's has played. From
the above total we see that the average score
for each game is 18 to 8. This average shows
two things: First, that the St. John's backfield is wonderfully aggressive on the offensive,
and second, that their defence is a trifle weak.
The St. John's back-field is composed of
Grove, fullback; Warfield, left halfback; and
Ruhl, right halfback. These men are all
reliable ground-gainers. Ruhl is probably
the star of the trio, for his end-running and
forward-passing have been responsible for

extent, but Butler, the sub-quarter, played an

The Black and Blue record this year is too
well known for a recital. In the six games
played we have scored 49 points to our opponpents' 28. Our line will be greatly
strengthened, we hope, by the return of Captain Stockton and Owens. The latest St.

team the Thursday after the St. John's game.
The Medicos will be no cinch this year, for
they are fast, and outweigh our men by about

FOOTBALL MASS MEETING.
A particularly successful mass meeting was
held in Hopkins Hall, on Monday, the 16th,
to practice yells for the St. John's game. A
big crowd was out. The first speaker was
Dr. George L. P. Radcliffe, '97, to whom
much of the credit for the reunion is due.
He asked for the support of the undergraduates, and was greeted with rousing
cheers. Mr. Stuart S. Janney, '95, was the
next speaker. Mr. Janney's presence was
quite appropriate, as his own doughty deeds
against St. John's have become a Hopkins
tradition. Mr. Stephen P. Harwood, '99, a
former chief rooter, also made a speech and
promised a large band of alumni to help in
the rooting.
It was announced that Hopkins has secured
the 300 seats in the stand nearest the center of
the field. Alumni and undergraduates will
gather here around their class banners. At
present writing, the band fund will be large
enough to have a fine band.

EDITORIAL.
HERE is great excitement among the students and this is due to the
approach of that momentous event which will take place next week,
the Hopkins—St. John's game. Everyone is discussing our prospects and all of the 'true sports" among the undergraduates are looking for bets. This year there will be no odds given by either side,
so far as we have been able to ascertain. Hopkins is doing every
,'11(
possible thing to back up the team, and we feel confident that the
ifsvvvvvvvv11
I
team will make every effort to win. We must win, and we will win.
The alumni are giving us as much support'as they can, in that
that they will turn out in large numbers to root for their Alma Mater,
and it is the duty of every undergraduate to be present at the game and to add his lusty
cheers to those of the alumni. We are sure that the undergraduates will make a good showing, but we want to be able to say that there was not one undergraduate who was not at the
game. A movement is on foot among the collegiate students to have a large band to play for
them at the game. This is an excellent idea, and should most certainly be encouraged and
carried out.
Our team will not be the only one which will have large crowds to back it, as the St.
John's alumni have been very busy organizing a reunion, and they will attend the game in a
large body accompanied by a band, which will try to drown the yells, songs and band of the
Hopkins men.

A NEGLECTED CLASSIC.
HERBERT E. GREENE.

A recent correspondent of the Nation tells
of several amusing experiences that he has had
in teaching the Bible. On one occasion be
asked a class of forty, 'How many of you
college men think you could find the book of
Hezekiah in the Bible without using the index ?" Fifteen of the forty were certain that
they could accomplish this feat if they were
allowed five minutes for the search. A few
weeks later he put the same question to
another class of thirteen college men, every
one of whom was confident of success. Similar
experiences might be related by many who
have undertaken to teach college students.
Most teachers would agree that it is scarcely
possible to overstate the lack of familiarity
with the Bible that is shown to-day by young
men and women who are called educated.
Yet there can be no question as to the practical unanimity with which people affirm that
of all books the Bible is the most important.
It is a matter of common knowledge that
the Bible is more frequently quoted than any
other book,—often by those who would be
puzzled indeed if they were asked to trace
their quotations. English literature is saturated with Biblical allusion and Biblical quotation to such an extent that a reader who
has only a slight acquaintance with the Bible
cannot hope to read understandingly or appreciatively such poets as Chaucer, Spenser,
Shakspere, Milton, Dryden, Pope, Wordsworth, Byron, Tennyson, Browning, prose
writers such as Bacon, Burke, Carlyle, Ruskin,
Matthew Arnold. This means that practically
all of our great writers and most of our lesser
writers were Bible-reading men and women,
and that they assumed a familiarity with the
Bible on the part of those for whom they
wrote. A recent writer has not been guilty
of over-statement when he says, ``Certainly
an intimate acquaintance with the Bible is the
best possible preparation for a study of English literature." One may even venture to
assert that familiarity with the Bible is necessary to an understanding of the daily papers
and the current magazines.* Says another
recent writer, "The Biblical tradition impreg*The last number of Life assumes a knowledge of
the story of two of our Old Testament prophets.

nates all our fashions of thinking and speaking. A man totally unacquainted with the
sacred history would go through the world as
if deaf or blind. A people which loses familiarity with the Bible is exiled from its spiritual
and intellectual fatherland, and becomes a
tribe of outlaws." A prominent American
scholar has written of the Bible in the following words:—"These books contain a body of
history, poetry, and philosophy, the study of
which has done more than any other single
cause to modify the course and happiness of
thinking men on earth, and to color and direct
the whole course of modern civilization."
Those who read various statements regarding the ignorance of college students with a
smile of superiority,—a feeling that is not
always warranted,—are apt to reflect, sometimes to comment, upon how little the college
has done for the student. As a matter of fact,
the tests of college classes that we read of
from time to time are commonly made with
Freshmen.t These tests both indicate an interest on the part of the college, and show
that the responsibility for ignorance must be
placed farther back than the college. Most
classes contain a few students who show a
reasonable degree of familiarity with the Bible;
it usually appears that such familiarity has
been gained, not in the school, nor yet in the
church, but in the home. It is there, in
truth, that such an acquaintance is most
readily gained. Fathers and mothers who
really believe that an intimate knowledge of
the Bible is important will see to it that such
knowledge is gained in the home. No child
should be defrauded of an early acquaintance
with Jack and the Beanstalk and Little Red
Riding Hood; and among his early heroes,
endeared by long association, should be
Joseph and Moses, Gideon and David. Soon
after he knows by heart his nursery rhymes
he is ready to be taught the Ten Commandments and the Beatitudes.
The question may be raised, what is done
by the colleges for students who appear to be
so greatly in need of Bible instruction? Are
these students less ignorant when they
graduate than they are when they enter? The
I.Interesting accounts of tests of this kind may be
found in the Century for May, 1900, pages 123-128,
and for December, 1900, pages 273-276.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

colleges, it may be answered, do not undertake the kind of instruction that properly belongs to the church and the home; but many
colleges do provide systematic instruction in
the Bible, both in the original languages and
in English. In some colleges such courses
are prescribed; more frequently, however,
they are elective. Courses of the latter kind
are provided by the Johns Hopkins University.
The effect of an intimate acquaintance with
the Bible upon one's style is well known.
"Intense study of the Bible," says Coleridge,
"will keep any writer from being vulgar in
point of style." Other faults he may have,
but not the fault of common-placeness; his
diction is likely to be simple, choice, dignified. Acting upon this belief, we require of
every freshman the reading of a number of
English classics,—by Shakespere, Milton,
Thackeray, Hawthorne, for example,—and,
with these classics, of considerable portions of
the English Bible. We ask our students to
read the Bible as they read other literature,
several pages at a time; we do not ask them
to make a minute study of a few verses, tho
that method of study is sometimes necessary
and helpful to a better understanding both of
the Bible and of English literature. We have
received repeated testimony that never before
has the Bible been found so interesting as
when it has been studied as literature,—the
only phase of Bible study that our department can properly deal with.
One sometimes hears the question raised as
to whether a body of religious writings can
successfully be taught to students of various
religious faiths. The answer is, obviously,
that it can be taught, as has repeatedly been
done with success, if it is taught as literature.
Objections might, indeed, he made by narrowminded men; but I have never heard of such
objections at this university. Rather I have
found a keen and broad-minded interest in
whatever has been of interest to humanity.
All religious classics are deeply interesting,
most of all for us the great Hebrew and
Hellenistic classics that have had so profound
and far-reaching an influence upon all civilized nations. It would manifestly be improper to make use of university classes for
teaching one's own religious views; but if

5

some of our English poems, by Wordsworth
and Shelley for example, cannot be understood without reference to the teaching of
Plato, much less can English literature, in its
long history of twelve hundred years, be
understood by one who is unacquainted with
the Old and the New Testaments. One who
does not know the beautiful story of Ruth cannot fully enjoy Keats's Ode lo a Nightingale;
one who has not read the book of Judges cannot understand Tennyson's Dream of Fair
Women; one who is not acquainted with the
parables of Jesus misses something when he
tries to read Tennyson's Guinevere. It for this
reason that considerable portions of the Bible
are included in the freshman course of reading; that an historical sketch of the English
Bible is included in one of our elective courses;
and that in the study of any author a familiarity with Biblical quotations and allusions is
expected wherever such familiarity is needed
for an understanding of the thought and
meaning of that author.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—The inter-fraternity treaty proposed
by THE NEWS-LETTER is the right sort. Perhaps the plan is too complicated to work.
Maybe the proposed inter-fraternity secretary
would know too much about the affairs of
other fraternities than his own. Perhaps the
penalty is vague. Anybody can find some
fault with the scheme. But that's no reason
for not having any scheme at all. Unless a
man can deny the truth of your preamble (I
don't see how he can) he ought to favor your
plan or a better one. What we want now is
to see the active members of the Hopkins
fraternities get together and talk the matter
over sensibly. When they agree on a plan,
let them go ahead. If one or two fainthearted chapters won't come in, let them stay
out; and public opinion,particularly fraternityalumni opinion, will be squarely behind the
chapters that stands for dignity and public
spirit. In the end, those chapters will get all
the good men they want, for the good men
will wait to see what they are going to do.

ALUMNUS.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

6
_

To the Board of Editors
of THE NEWS- LETTER:

DEAR SIR—The fraternity treaty recently
proposed by THE NEWS-LETTER has left
many of us in a haze of doubt over the practibility of it. Here are several points that the
author, or authors, have evidently overlooked.
First, they say that the treaty is founded
upon the inter-club treaty at Princeton; evidently they are unaware that last year two of
the leading clubs at Princeton dropped out of
the treaty, saying, that while they considered
the idea of the treaty sound, that it was tinpracticable, because there was no way to
enforce it.
The same is true of the situation at Johns
Hopkins. While the idea of the treaty is
good, so far as all practicable purpose goes, it
is worthless. Such a treaty must have as its
foundation, either perfect confidence between
the fraternities, or some penalty so severe,
that the breaking of the treaty would be out
of the question. At a Pan-Hellenic Council,
last year, a treaty along these same general
lines was agitated, its purpose being to put a
stop to early pledging. This treaty failed to
be adopted for the reason that the several
fraternities at the University were unwilling
to enter into an agreement with each other
where the honor of the fraternities was the
only guarantee of the treaty being kept. This
situation is indeed lamentable, but is only the
direct result of inter-fraternity politics during
the last few years.
The penalty proposed in the NEws-LETTER
treaty is utterly inadequate. ''In case of a
charge being brought against a fraternity, the
delegates of that fraternity to the Pan-Hellenic
Council, shall investigate the charge and
report their findings in the same to the council
That is all very well, but if the accusation is
true, how much may you expect the members
of the fraternity to admit? From my experience with inter-fraternity policies at Hopkins,
I should scarcely expect to find a fraternity
sacrificing itself to the general good. And
again the secret nature of fraternities is such
that no one but a member of the fraternity
would be in a position to investigate the
charge against the said fraternity. Here, we
have all the Princeton troubles at their worst

with an added complication in the way of the
secret nature of a fraternity.
Again, can a fraternity situated in a city,
with a large number of alumni about it, be
responsible for the actions of those alumni?
The Princeton clubs had no such alumni in
daily contact with it. Article III, Section 6,
Clause 2, provides that if an incoming freshman is unable to sign the oath in Article III,
Section 5, through action on his part caused
by ignorance of the conditions that he be at
liberty to join any fraternity sending him an
invitation, no previous pledge being binding.
What is to prevent an alumnus of a chapter
pledging a man before entrance? The fraternity with all fairness, may disclaim all responsibility for the action of the alumnus, yet
reap the benefits of it.
The only clause in the treaty which would be
of practical use is that clause which prohibits
sub-freshman the privilege of entering a
fraternity house before March 1st, of the year
before they enter. But with Hopkins, the
men are not sure just what year they will
enter, so in many cases this rule may be
broken through no intention of the fraternity.
And this clause alone would be of little use in
breaking up the present abuses.
A house of cards balanced upon a toothpick is not a very edifying sight. The authors
of THE NEWS-LETTER treaty seem to count
it nothing that their treaty has already
failed under much more favorable conditions
than are offered at Hopkins, and that several
of the Hopkins fraternities have within the
last year signified their unwillingness to enter
into any treaty of this nature.
Very truly yours,
ALAN CHuRcHILL WOODS.
November 14, 1908.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
At a meeting of the Trustees held November 2nd, President Remsen resigned the position of Director of the Chemical Laboratory,
which he has held from the beginning of the
University. Prof. Harmon N. Morse was
appointed Director of the Chemical Laboratory
and his title changed to that of Professor of
Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry. President Remsen will continue to lecture as in
past years and to take the same part in the
work of the advanced students.

The laying of a new ceiling over the rooms
of the Classical Department proves to be
quite a noisy affair. Someone has suggested
that we have here a revival of the "Lays of
Ancient Rome."

About time for another afternoon tea, isn't

hold its first dance on the night of December,
the fourth. It is desirable that everyone
attend the dances of the Cotillon Club, if he
can possibly arrange to do so. We trust that
abundance of chaperons will be provided.

French Revolution, have been interesting

Robbins nipped through on the inside. The
boring by Carpenter continued, and the umpires held up their hands to signal the
foul.
The judges, Messrs. Parry, Pennycook and
Fisher, consulted with Mr. David ScottDuncan, and on the evidence of the umpires
the race was declared void.
The result of the inquiry was the following
decision, signed by Messrs. Parry, Pennycook
and Fisher, the judges: '`We, the under-.
signed, being judges of the final of the 400
metres, declare the race void, and order same
to be re-run on Saturday next without Car-

penter, he being disqualified, and further
order that the race be run in strings."
Yours respectfully,
Pm-A' S. BULLEN.

ST. JOHN'S AND B. M. C.
When the 'Varsity team meets St. John's
in the annual big game next Saturday, one of
the toughest football battles ever fought in
this city will undoubtedly result. St. John's
has the greatest team in its history this year,
and the same may be said of Hopkins, for our
team has made a great record this year. Our
defeat at the hands of Delaware was one of
those things that will happen to the best of
teams when luck, weather conditions and
sickness are against them.
St. John's has played eight games this year
and has won six of them, losing to the University of Virginia and the Naval Academy.
Their record up-to-date stands, 147 points
won against 63 lost. This is certainly an
enviable record when one thinks of the caliber
of the teams that St. John's has played. From
the above total we see that the average score
for each game is 18 to 8. This average shows
two things: First, that the St. John's backfield is wonderfully aggressive on the offensive,
and second, that their defence is a trifle weak.
The St. John's back-field is composed of
Grove, fullback; Warfield, left halfback; and
Ruhl, right halfback. These men are all
reliable ground-gainers. Ruhl is probably
the star of the trio, for his end-running and
forward-passing have been responsible for

Our team will be greatly handicapped by

The Medicos will be no cinch this year, for
they are fast, and outweigh our men by about

FOOTBALL MASS MEETING.
A particularly successful mass meeting was
held in Hopkins Hall, on Monday, the 16th,
to practice yells for the St. John's game. A
big crowd was out. The first speaker was
Dr. George L. P. Radcliffe, '97, to whom
much of the credit for the reunion is due.
He asked for the support of the undergraduates, and was greeted with rousing
cheers. Mr. Stuart S. Janney, '95, was the
next speaker. Mr. Janney's presence was
quite appropriate, as his own doughty deeds
against St. John's have become a Hopkins
tradition. Mr. Stephen P. Harwood, '99, a
former chief rooter, also made a speech and
promised a large band of alumni to help in
the rooting.
It was announced that Hopkins has secured
the 300 seats in the stand nearest the center of
the field. Alumni and undergraduates will
gather here around their class banners. At
present writing, the band fund will be large
enough to have a fine band.
